titleStmt.title: VISUAL AIDS AND FINANCIAL DECISION MAKING

analytic.title: VISUAL AIDS AND FINANCIAL DECISION MAKING

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Numeracy is the ability to understand, manipulate, and make sense of numerical information. It is crucial for everyday decision making that involves dealing with numbers. In this study, we tested whether we can help people make better choices in monetary lotteries by communicating numerical values (i.e., payoffs and probabilities) using visual aids. We also checked whether presenting this information in a visual form reduces math-related anxiety and global affect negativity. Participants (N = 210) made choices in ten monetary lotteries accompanied with visual aids (experimental condition) or without visual aids (control condition). After the lottery task, participants completed questionnaires measuring experienced emotions and numerical skills. We found that in a visual aid condition, participants who were relatively less educated scored significantly higher in a lottery task (made more expected value consistent choices) in comparison to those in the control condition. Moreover, participants in the visual aid condition reported significantly lower intensity of negative emotions after the lottery task than those in the control condition. We argue that visual aids are a promising tool for future learning, and their simplicity and friendly format can positively influence people's decisions in situations involving risk in health, finance, or in a school context.

div.head: VISUAL AIDS AND FINANCIAL DECISION MAKING 3
Public Significance Statement
div.p: This study examines whether people make better financial decisions when numerical information is communicated in a graphic form. Such visual aids have proven to be particularly helpful for individuals with relatively lower levels of education. This implies that those aids can support decision-making process in risky situations. Implementing similar tools in finance, health, or education domains is a promising way that can have a beneficial effect on a larger audience.

VISUAL AIDS AND FINANCIAL DECISION MAKING 4 Every day we have to make decisions involving numerical information and people with higher objective (statistical) numeracy -an ability to understand and use numbers, perform arithmetic operations, and compare numerical magnitudesmay consistently make them better (Cokely et al., 2018;Garcia-Retamero et al., 2019;Peters, 2020). It has been shown that those people are less affected by emotions irrelevant to the decision-making process (Traczyk & Fulawka, 2016), have larger assets (Estrada-Mejia et al., 2020), or make more choices consistent with the Expected Value principle (EV; the sum of payoffs multiplied by their probabilities; Peters & Bjalkebring, 2015;Sobkow et al., 2020).

Nevertheless, objective numeracy could be complementary to subjective numeracy (Peters et al., 2019;Peters & Bjalkebring, 2015), which refers to trust in one's ability to perform mathematical tasks and a preference for a numerical instead of verbal format. People with higher subjective numeracy experience fewer negative emotions when thinking about numbers and have lower math anxiety (Peters & Bjalkebring, 2015;Sobkow et al., 2023).

Math anxiety refers to negative feelings of tension or fear caused by performance which involves mathematical reasoning (Ashcraft, 2002). Further, it disrupts and overloads working memory during mathematical tasks (Maloney & Beilock, 2012) and decreases engagement in situations where mathematical operations must be performed. On the other hand, numeracy facilitates computation, encourages more information seeking and greater depth processing, improves interpretation of the meaning of provided numbers, and promotes behavioral change (Lipkus & Peters, 2009). Supporting numeracy is an important direction that can affect well-being in terms of financial decisions and those related to health (Peters, 2020). There are two possible directions to support numeracy and decision making: long-term target interventions, related to the implementation of special education programs designed to develop specific problem-solving skills (e.g., Cohen Kadosh et al., 2013;Sobkow et al., 2019), and short-term, focused on risk communication formats, such as percentages, graphs, VISUAL AIDS AND FINANCIAL DECISION MAKING 5 and charts (Garcia-Retamero & Cokely, 2017). This study is devoted to graphic aids, hereafter referred to as ''visual aids.''

div.head: Visual aids
div.p: A visual aid is a format in which numerical information is presented as a, typically colorful, visualization. Particular types of visual aids can serve specific purposes, but, overall, they are mainly used to communicate risk, uncertainty, and interactions among different risk factors (Lipkus & Hollands, 1999). They can help overcome difficulties with understanding numerical information by attracting and holding people's attention. Visual aids may also work by encouraging deliberative thinking, surpassing beliefs caused by anecdotal narratives, increasing risk avoidance, and promoting healthy behaviors. Deliberative thinking can be described as characteristic of system 2 -that is, slow, where operations in the mind are conscious, controlled, and require some mental effort (Kahneman, 2011). Deliberation promotes more thorough, complex, and durable information representations (Cokely & Kelley, 2009). Developing formats that gives a "feel" of the weight of decisions and their consequences can raise motivation to make more appropriate decisions (Petrova et al., 2016). Thus, it can be assumed that using such formats may allow less numerate people to derive affective and gist-like judgments from numbers to support their decision-making process (Peters & Shoots-Reinhard, 2022). Using visual aids can help people who are not good at understanding numbers to think more carefully about risk, and to better understand the problem (Garcia-Retamero et al., 2019).

Secondly, visual aids may surpass beliefs caused by anecdotal evidence. When it comes to evaluating scientific news articles, anecdotal stories can discourage and decrease one's ability to reason (Rodriguez et al., 2016). The same situation refers to numerical reasoning. Fagerlin et al. (2005) found that when statistical information is provided in text format, the percentage of information about the correct choice of medical treatment can be VISUAL AIDS AND FINANCIAL DECISION MAKING 6 surpassed by anecdotal information. However, when statistics were reinforced with pictographs, the influence of anecdotes was no longer significant.

Thirdly, visual aids may increase risk avoidance and promote healthy behaviors. A study by Schirillo & Stone (2005) showed that adding a simple visual representation of injury numbers in the form of asterisks to statistical information increased participants' willingness to spend more money on safer tires for the purpose of reducing harm. In addition, Cox et al. (2010) found that presenting information in a graphic format increased mothers' intention to vaccinate their daughters with the HPV vaccine, while a study by Vogt & Marteau (2012) showed that using a visual format can increase the chances of quitting smoking. Moreover, using visual aids to communicate the real win rates in a gambling game resulted in participants feeling less likely to win a prize, reporting less excitement, and feeling less inclined to gamble (Walker et al., 2023).

div.head: Study Goals
div.p: The results cited above suggest that statistical information conveyed using visual aids may help individuals who experience difficulties in understanding standard numerical formats. In the current study, we would like to go further and answer two questions: (1) Can more complex information be conveyed using visual aids? (2) Can visual aids reduce affect negativity?

Expanding on the first question, we argue that visual aids may not only show simple information as trends or proportions (Garcia-Retamero & Cokely, 2013) but also more complex: probabilities and payoffs. In our study, we are going to use a format that integrates both probabilities (for a win or loss) and the amount of the reward that this decision entails.

Referring to the second question we posed, a decision problem involving numerical information may evoke math anxiety which may impede cognitive processing. At this point, several effective interventions aimed at lowering math anxiety have been developed (e.g., VISUAL AIDS AND FINANCIAL DECISION MAKING 7 Brunyé et al., 2013;Park et al., 2014). These interventions confirm that focusing on the affective component can be a good solution to mitigate math anxiety. We assume that presenting a mathematical problem in a "friendly" -visual -format may cause the subjects to experience less negative emotions, prevent them from eliciting negative thoughts related to mathematical content and create more precise representations of numerical magnitude (Maloney et al., 2011).

Referring to the above considerations, we have derived two main hypotheses: H1: Participants who are presented with lottery tasks in a visual form will make better decisions (consistent with the EV) compared to the control group.

div.head: H2:
div.p: Presenting lottery tasks in a visual form will reduce math-related anxiety and improve the affect positivity of participants.

div.head: Methods
div.p: The study was preregistered on the Open Science Framework (OSF; https://osf.io/fzqtu) platform, and all materials and dataset used can be obtained under this link: osf.io/zaxfq.

div.head: Participants
div.p: The final sample contained 210 participants (82% female; Mage= 26.55, SDage = 7.43 years). Most participants (56%) had a secondary education, while the rest had a university degree. Details about participants' flow and power analysis are described in supplementary online materials (SOM). The study was approved by the departmental Ethical Committee.

div.head: VISUAL AIDS AND FINANCIAL DECISION MAKING 8
Design and materials
div.p: Participants were randomly assigned to one of the two between-subjects experimental conditions: respondents had to answer 10 lottery tasks with visual aids (experimental group) or without (control group). The visual aids were designed so that the size of the colored field represents a value consistent with the EV, as seen in Figure 1. The experimental group received two preliminary tasks to check their understanding of the graph. Afterward, by using questionnaires, we assessed participants' affect negativity and positivity as well as statistical numeracy, subjective numeracy, and math anxiety.

div.head: Lottery task
div.p: This task consisted of 10 items with two possible options to choose from (Cokely & Kelley, 2009). Participants had to decide which option was more attractive. Order and the position of option A or B on the page were randomized. In the control condition, this task was presented in text form. In the experimental condition, this task was presented in visual form (see Figure 1). The correctness of the chosen option in both conditions was evaluated in terms of EV.

div.head: Affect positivity
div.p: We used the BERRI (Petrova et al., 2022) Example of decisions from experimental trials.

Note. Participants selected the option they wanted to choose. At one time, two options were presented on the screen. Respondents were able to decide whether they preferred option a or a' -when the question was about potential gain (green color) and b or b' -when the question was about loss (red color). We also used a programming extension to make sure the figures were displayed at the right size and no details were missed.

div.head: VISUAL AIDS AND FINANCIAL DECISION MAKING 10
Statistical numeracy
div.p: We used the Berlin Numeracy Test (BNT; Cokely et al., 2012). BNT contains four tasks requiring the use of statistical and probability information. Scores on the test ranged from 0 to 4 points, with higher scores indicating higher statistical numeracy.

div.head: Subjective Numeracy
div.p: Subjective numeracy was measured with the eight-item Subjective Numeracy Scale (Fagerlin et al., 2007). Participants answered each question using a six-point scale to assess their perceived numerical abilities and preference for numerical information. Higher scores indicated being more confident with numbers.

div.head: Math anxiety
div.p: We used the Math Anxiety Questionnaire for Adults (MAQA; Szczygieł, 2022). For each of the 19 items, participants are asked to declare the level of anxiety that they would feel in hypothetical situations involving numbers. The higher the score, the higher of math anxiety.

div.head: Impact of visual aids on lottery choices
div.p: To verify H1 and check whether the presentation of lottery tasks in a visual form affects the relevance of the response in accordance with the EV, we conducted an independent sample one-tailed t-test. Results of the analysis revealed only weak evidence that participants from the experimental condition scored higher in the lottery task t(208) = 1.43, p = .077, d = 0.20, than those from the control condition (M = 7.96, SD = 1.63; M = 7.64, SD = 1.67); as seen in Table s1 (SOM). This effect was not moderated by objective numeracy CI [-0.33, 0.47] As a part of the exploratory analysis, we decided to include the level of education as a possible moderator of this relationship. A 2 (experimental condition) x 2 (level of education) two-way between-groups analysis of variance revealed a significant main effect of education, F(1, 209) = 15.10, p < .001, η 2 = 0.07, which was further qualified by a significant two-way interaction, F(1,209) = 5.08, p = .025, η 2 = 0.02 (see Figure 2). Participants with a secondary (lower) education scored significantly higher in the lottery task with visual aids than their counterparts in the control condition (M = 8.55, SD = 1.31 and M = 7.80, SD = 1.66; respectively, p < .05). With visual aids they scored even higher than participants with a university degree (M = 8.55, SD = 1.31 and M = 7.20, SD = 1.69; respectively, p < .001). No effects were observed between higher and lower education groups in the control condition (p = .245), and in participants with a university degree across the visual and non-visual format of the lottery task (M = 7.20, SD = 1.69 and M = 7.44, SD = 1.69; respectively, p = .471).

div.head: Impact of visual aids on affect
div.p: To verify H2 and check whether the presentation of lottery tasks in a visual form has an impact on affect, we conducted an independent sample one-tailed t-test. We found that participants from the experimental condition reported significantly lower intensity of negative emotions measured by a negative component of the BERRI scale, t(208) = 1.90, p = .029, d = 0.26, than those from the control condition (M = 1.81, SD = 0.99; M = 2.10, SD = 1.23; respectively). We found no differences between groups on other scales (see Table s1; SOM).
Descriptive statistics, reliability, and exploratory analyses (relationships among measures, deliberation times, and predictors of lottery task choices) could be found in SOM.

div.head: Summed Lottery Task Scores
div.p: Note. Number of choices maximizing Expected Value in non-graphic format and graphic format across participants with a secondary education and university degree.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: In this study, we aimed to answer two main questions: (1) Can more complex information be conveyed using visual aids? (2) Can visual aids reduce affect negativity? Based on the study results, we can cautiously conclude that the answer is: yes. In our study, people with a relatively lower level of education particularly benefited from visual aids, and for those with a higher education, the level of performance remained unchanged. These results are in line with other studies, in which visual aids were found to be particularly effective in improving the understanding of risk communications for people with lower cognitive abilities (Apter et al., VISUAL AIDS AND FINANCIAL DECISION MAKING 13 2008;Garcia-Retamero & Cokely, 2013). Nevertheless, future studies should aim to obtain more diverse samples (e.g., from the general population) and use objective numeracy measures more suitable for people with a lower level of education (e.g., Weller et al., 2013) to cover the full spectrum of this variable. Importantly, we also observed a significant reduction in negative affect linked to performing a lottery task in a visual form, compared to the standard format, reflected by the BERRI negative component. However, we observed no significant differences in the other measures we used. A likely explanation for this may be that BERRI is specifically validated for measuring positive and negative feelings about risk in real-life situations (Petrova et al., 2022).

In this study, the risk was hypothetical, and those tested did not lose or win real money. What remained real was performing the task; thus, subjects may have felt tension or fear caused by performing a task that requires mathematical reasoning, and which was reduced by using a visual format.

Summarizing the results of this study, complex information can be conveyed using visual aids. We used a format that integrates both: probabilities (for a win or lose) and the amount of the reward that this decision entails. The complexity of the task did not prevent the test subjects from performing the task correctly, and for those with a relatively lower level of education, they proved to be helpful. The visual aids we used also lowered the negative affect experienced by the subjects. In conclusion, visual aids are a very promising direction for future learning, and their simplicity, as well as friendly format, can positively influence people's decisions in situations involving risk in health, finance, or in a school context.

div.head: Funding
div.p: This work was supported the National Science Centre, Poland [2018/31/D/HS6/02899].

figure.head: Figure 1
figure.figDesc: and items adapted from Brooks and Schweitzer (2011), as measures of affect positivity and negativity. The BERRI scale contains six adjectives (positive: assured, hopeful, relieved; negative: anxious, afraid, worried), and items from Brooks and Schweitzer contain four (positive: excited, enthusiastic; negative: tense, nervous). These adjectives were randomized and presented to participants on one screen after the lottery task. VISUAL AIDS AND FINANCIAL DECISION MAKING 9
